Title: Architectonics of the parietal and temporal association cortex in the strepsirhine primate Galago compared to the anthropoid primate Macaca
Abstract: "A number of higher order association areas have been described in the parietal and temporal cortex of large-brained anthropoid primates such as Macaca. However, little is known about the evolution of these areas, and the existence of homologous areas has not yet been clearly demonstrated in other mammalian groups. We addressed this issue by comparing the myelo- and cytoarchitecture of posterior association cortex in the anthropoid Macaca to that of the small-brained, strepsirhine ("prosimian") primate Galago. Our results suggest that Galago possesses many, if not most, of the areas present in Macaca. We were able to identify regions in Galago which resemble Macaca posterior parietal area 7, superior temporal polysensory cortex (ST), inferotemporal visual cortex (IT), the temporoparietal auditory area (Tpt), and posterior parahippocampal cortex (areas TH and TF). Area 7, ST, and IT can each be subdivided further in Macaca, and for most of these subdivisions we were able to identify counterparts in Galago. However, we could not distinguish as many divisions of ST cortex in Galago as in Macaca, and it is possible that new areas arose in this region during anthropoid evolution. There also appear to be general differences in architectonic organization between these animals, with Macaca exhibiting greater development of pyramidal layer IIIc and of the internal granular layer (IV) across much of the parieto-temporal cortex. These findings suggest that many, although possibly not all, of the parietal and temporal association areas present in the modern anthropoid Macaca evolved early in primate history, prior to the divergence of the lineages leading to strepsirhines and anthropoids."
Comments: The relations of Bonin and Bailey's area PE to Brodmann's map as indicated by Figure 9B is in strong contradiction to the original description of BB47 (see pp. 36, 72 of BB47). Therefore, we have not entered this relation.

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation: "In a previous study (Preuss and Goldman-Rakic, 1991a), we compared the myelo- and cytoarchitectonic organization of granular frontal cortex (GFC) in the strepsirhine Galago and the anthropoid primate Macaca. Here we extend our comparative archotectonic investigation of primate association areas to the parietal and temporal cortex." (p. 475)

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Fig. 9. Summary of published interpretations of area 7 and its subdivisions in Macaca and other Old World monkeys. A: According to Brodmann (1909), area 7 covers the inferior parietal lobule [IPL] on the lateral surface and much of the medial surface of the parietal lobe. Subsequent authors have subdivided Brodmann's area 7. B: Vogt and Vogt (1919) divided the IPL cortex into separate anterior and posterior areas, termed 7b and 7a, as did Bonin and Bailey (1947), who termed these areas PF and PG." (p. 491, legend to Fig. 9)

"Brodmann (1905, 1908, 1909) designated a large region of posterior parietal cortex in primates as area 7. Subsequent investigations, mainly in Macaca, have demonstrated that area 7 is not in fact a single area but rather a heterogeneous group of areas...The parcellation of Macaque area 7 followed in this study is shown in Fig. 4...IPL [inferior parietal lobule] and LS [lateral sylvian] areas. The organization of this part of the area 7 complex appears to be quite similar in Macaca and Galago; we have been able to identify four areas in both taxa...We divide the IPL cortex into an anterior zone, area 7b, and a posterior zone, 7a, and further divided the latter zone into a lateral area (7a-l), located along the convexity of the IPL, and a medial area (7a-m), located along the rim of the IPS. An additional area, 7op, occupies the dorsal bank of the LS (i.e., the parietal operculum) immediately ventral to the IPL." (pp. 482-483)

Subsequent authors have subdivided Brodmann's area 7... C: Pandya and Seltzer (1982; Selter and Pandya, 1980, 1983) divided the area 7 complex extensively." (p. 491, legend to Fig. 9)
@InterMapRelations.Comments:
Neither SP80 nor PS82 show an area IPd. This area was defined by the same authors a few years later (SP86).
SP83 is an SocNeurosci-abstract.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Fig. 9. Summary of published interpretations of area 7 and its subdivisions in Macaca and other Old World monkeys. A: According to Brodmann (1909), area 7 covers the inferior parietal lobule [IPL] on the lateral surface and much of the medial surface of the parietal lobe. Subsequent authors have subdivided Brodmann's area 7... C: Pandya and Seltzer (1982; Selter and Pandya, 1980, 1983) divided the area 7 complex extensively. They recognized the architectonic distinctiveness of the cortex within the IPS (areas POa-e and POa-i) and also affirmed the architectonic likeness of the medial parietal cortex (their area PGm) to the cortex of the inferior parietal lobule." (p. 491, legend to Fig. 9)
@InterMapRelations.Comments:
PS82 only refers to "area POa" without distinguishing between the subdivisions POa-i and POa-e that were explicitly defined by SP80.
SP83 is an SocNeurosci-abstract.

"Temporal extrastriate cortex. (p. 495)

"The fundus of the STS...is comprised of two areas, PGa and IPa...As described by Seltzer and Pandya (1978), IPA covers most of the broad floor of the sulcus, whereas PGa lies along the sulcus that marks the dorsal limit of the fundus. These areas are very similar to architectonically, and we found it difficult to distinguish them consistently." (p. 495)

"Temporal extrastriate cortex. In anthropoids there are several visuotopically organized areas which are located posterior to ST and IT at the temporo-occipital junction (Fig. 4E). (p. 495)

"Temporal extrastriate cortex. "Brodmann (1905, 1908, 1909) designated a large region of posterior parietal cortex in primates as area 7. Subsequent investigations, mainly in Macaca, have demonstrated that area 7 is not in fact a single area but rather a heterogeneous group of areas...The parcellation of Macaque area 7 followed in this study is shown in Fig. 4...IPL [inferior parietal lobule] and LS [lateral sylvian] areas. The organization of this part of the area 7 complex appears to be quite similar in Macaca and Galago; we have been able to identify four areas in both taxa...We divide the IPL cortex into an anterior zone, area 7b, and a posterior zone, 7a, and further divided the latter zone into a lateral area (7a-l), located along the convexity of the IPL, and a medial area (7a-m), located along the rim of the IPS. An additional area, 7op, occupies the dorsal bank of the LS (i.e., the parietal operculum) immediately ventral to the IPL." (pp. 482-483)

publication.title: Architectonics of the parietal and temporal association cortex in the strepsirhine primate Galago compared to the anthropoid primate Macaca
publication.abstract: "A number of higher order association areas have been described in the parietal and temporal cortex of large-brained anthropoid primates such as Macaca. However, little is known about the evolution of these areas, and the existence of homologous areas has not yet been clearly demonstrated in other mammalian groups. We addressed this issue by comparing the myelo- and cytoarchitecture of posterior association cortex in the anthropoid Macaca to that of the small-brained, strepsirhine ("prosimian") primate Galago. Our results suggest that Galago possesses many, if not most, of the areas present in Macaca. We were able to identify regions in Galago which resemble Macaca posterior parietal area 7, superior temporal polysensory cortex (ST), inferotemporal visual cortex (IT), the temporoparietal auditory area (Tpt), and posterior parahippocampal cortex (areas TH and TF). Area 7, ST, and IT can each be subdivided further in Macaca, and for most of these subdivisions we were able to identify counterparts in Galago. However, we could not distinguish as many divisions of ST cortex in Galago as in Macaca, and it is possible that new areas arose in this region during anthropoid evolution. There also appear to be general differences in architectonic organization between these animals, with Macaca exhibiting greater development of pyramidal layer IIIc and of the internal granular layer (IV) across much of the parieto-temporal cortex. These findings suggest that many, although possibly not all, of the parietal and temporal association areas present in the modern anthropoid Macaca evolved early in primate history, prior to the divergence of the lineages leading to strepsirhines and anthropoids."
